thread.title: Emmeline Pankhurst's great-granddaughter calls on women to stand up for their rights
thread.title_full: Emmeline Pankhurst's great-granddaughter calls on women to stand up for their rights

author: Vikki White
title: Emmeline Pankhurst's great-granddaughter calls on women to stand up for their rights
text:
Dr Helen Pankhurst is calling on women to stand up for their rights (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing!   
Emmeline Pankhurst’s great-granddaughter is calling on women across the UK to get out and stand up for their rights. 
Dr Helen Pankhurst will be one of the leading figures at today’s women’s march in London – like her great grandmother nearly a century ago. 
She says the famous suffragette would have been “horrified” by ­ Donald Trump , and urges that following his election, it’s more vital than ever that women stand together. 
“I think Emmeline, like most of us today, would have been horrified that a man who has bragged about assaulting women, and whose ­policies are regressive in terms of internationalism and feminism, has become the most powerful man in the world,” she said. Read More Mrs Emmeline Pankhurst (Photo: Getty) 
“She would be horrified but ­probably not surprised. 
“Misogyny has a habit of rearing its ugly head, and she would be out marching now with all of us.” 
Thousands are expected to take part in today’s #March4Women rally, led by Care International, to highlight the struggles women are currently facing around the globe ahead of Wednesday’s International Women’s Day. Emile Sande will lead the music at the end of the rally (Photo: Reuters) 
Infamous for his “grab her by the p***y” remarks, Trump’s election led to women’s marches around the world earlier this year. 
Helen said: “It’s not just about Trump – there are many other examples of sexism and a lack of support for diversity or willingness to reach out to the most vulnerable from those in positions of power right across the globe.” 
Great-grandmother Emmeline is considered one of the 20th century’s most important figures. Annie Lennox will also be at the march (Photo: Getty) 
Her grandmother, Sylvia Pankhurst, also became a ­driving force of the suffragettes. 
Helen will be joined today by ­Bianca Jagger, Annie Lennox and London mayor Sadiq Khan . 
The rally will end with a mass sing-along of Aretha Franklin’s Respect led by Emeli Sandé and Melanie C. 
Helen said: “If we didn’t have the vote we wouldn’t be marching today, but equally we need to campaign against current expressions of sexism and inequality to keep up pressure.” For more information, visit care international.org.uk/march4women Like us on Facebook
